prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Place of tort event

para.paratext: The location of an incident giving rise to multiple tort claims is one factor the Panel has cited as an important consideration affecting its choice of a transferee district. The Panel has stated a particular preference to transfer cases arising from air crash incidents to the district where the crash occurred.[1] This factor is also applied by the Panel to other mass torts.[2] This factor is different from the factors relating to the location of evidence, although the Panel's preference for transfer to the situs of the crash also recognizes the probable location of witnesses, documents, and the convenience of the parties. These factors are normally considered separately, however, and should be raised separately by counsel.[3] The Panel's preference for transferring air crash cases to the situs of the crash is not an iron-clad rule. The Panel considers each case on its individual facts and is willing to transfer these cases to other districts as may be appropriate.[4] In one case involving an in-flight fire resulting in an emergency crash landing in Kentucky, the Panel ordered the cases transferred to the Central District of California because the manufacturer, who would be the focus of the common liability discovery, was located there. The Panel also noted that the FAA had conducted its investigation there and that the plane had been certified by the FAA there.[5]

Cases involving foreign air crashes have been more problematic for the Panel. There are no fixed or general rules concerning an appropriate transferee district.[6] The Panel has rejected a rule of transfer to the district where the plane involved was manufactured.[7] The Panel has observed that foreign crashes may involve issues peculiarly related to the nation's capitol. In the cases arising from the 1983 downing of a Korean airliner by Soviet fighters, the Panel rejected five forums proposed by the parties in 42 actions, and transferred the cases instead to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, observing:

None of the five forums suggested by the parties as potential transferee districts could be characterized as the nexus of’ this litigation involving an overseas air disaster. On balance, however, we are persuaded that the District of Columbia is the appropriate transferee forum. Several governmental agencies located in or near the District of Columbia will likely be principal targets of discovery in these actions. Moreover, this air disaster and the resultant litigation implicate sensitive areas of national policy, international relations and military intelligence. These considerations, we find, favor selection of the District of Columbia as the transferee district.[8]

In a case arising from the crash in Newfoundland of a charter plane carrying 248 United States servicemen returning to their military base in Kentucky, the court selected the location of the decedents' base as the proper transferee forum.[9] In another case, the pendency of existing actions and the judge's overall caseload determined the transfer destination.[10] In a 2012 decision, the Panel centralized claims arising from a crash in Guyana in the Eastern District of New York, noting that the flight originated there, that the majority of the plaintiffs reside either in or near to that district, that the district was geographically accessible, and that an experienced judge was available to preside.[11]

Mass disasters other than plane crashes provide less clear-cut decisions of the Panel on the question of selection of a transferee district. Generally, however, the location of the disaster will be the most likely transferee district.[12] The location of a single incident of theft may be sufficient reason to favor a district.[13]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re: Air Crash at San Francisco, Cal., 987 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2013) (No. MDL 2497); In re: Air Crash Near Clarence Center, New York, on February 12, 2009, 655 F. Airport in Denver, Colo., on August 7, 1975, 447 F. Supp. 1071, 1072 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Air Crash Disaster at John F. Kennedy Intern. Airport on June 24, 1975, 407 F. Supp. 572 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Air Crash Disaster at Florida Everglades on December 29, 1972, 360 F. Supp. 1394 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Air Crash Disaster at Huntington, W. Supp. 45 (J.P.M.L. 1968); In re Civil Actions Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport, 295 F. Supp. 51 (J.P.M.L. 1968).

See, e.g., In re Terrorist Attacks on September 11, 2001, 295 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Train Derailment Near Amite, LA, on October 12, 2002, 269 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Rail Collision Near Chase, Md. on Jan. 4, 1987, 661 F. Supp. 69 (J.P.M.L. 1987); In re Fire Disaster at Dupont Plaza Hotel, San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Dec. 31, 1986, 660 F. Supp. 982 (J.P.M.L. 1987); In re Amtrak Train Derailment at Frankewing, Tenn., on October 1, 1975, 431 F. Supp. 916, 918 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Bomb Disaster at Roseville, California, on April 28, 1973, 399 F. Supp. 1400, 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
See, e.g., In re Civil Actions Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport, 295 F. Supp. 51 (J.P.M.L. 1968).

See, e.g., In re Air Crash Near Woodbury, Connecticut, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (despite crash in Connecticut, transfer to E.D.N.Y. because 1) aircraft and pilot were based there, 2) engine at issue was overhauled there, and 3) final flight's intended destination was there); In re Air Crash Disaster at Sioux City, Iowa, on July 19, 1989, 128 F.R.D. 131 (J.P.M.L. 1989); In re Air Disaster Near Brunswick, Ga., on Apr. 5, 1991, 794 F. Supp. 393 (J.P.M.L. 1992); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Pellston, Michigan, on May 9, 1970, 357 F. Supp. 1286 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Silver Plume, Colo., on October 2, 1970, 352 F. Supp. 968 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Air Crash Disaster at Juneau, Alaska on September 4, 1971, 350 F. Supp. 1163 (J.P.M.L. 1972).

In re Air Crash Disaster at Covington, Ky., on June 2, 1983, 579 F. Supp. 1057, 1058 (J.P.M.L. 1984). Accord In re Air Crash Near Van Cleve, Miss., on Aug. 13, 1977, 486 F. Supp. 926, 928 (J.P.M.L. 1980) (central location preferred to place of crash); In re Air Disaster at Denver, Colo., on Nov. 16, 1976, 486 F. Supp. 241, 243 (J.P.M.L. 1980) (place of manufacture of plane selected); In re Air Crash Disaster at Las Vegas, Nev. on October 8, 1968, 336 F. Supp. 414 (J.P.M.L. 1972).

See, e.g., In re Air Crash Disaster at Gander, Newfoundland, on Dec. 12, 1985, 633 F. Supp. 50 (J.P.M.L. 1986); In re Helicopter Crash in Germany on September 26, 1975, 443 F. Supp. 447, 449 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Saigon, South Vietnam, on April 4, 1975, 404 F. Supp. 478 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Air Disaster at San Antonio, Venezuela, 331 F. Supp. 547 (J.P.M.L. 1971).

See, e.g., In re Air Crash Disaster Near Saigon, South Vietnam, on April 4, 1975, 404 F. Supp. 478, 479 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Papeete, Tahiti, on July 22, 1973, 397 F. Supp. 886 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Air Crash Disaster at Pago Pago, Am. Samoa, on January 30, 1974, 383 F. Supp. 501 (J.P.M.L. 1974). But see In re Air Crash Near Athens, Greece, on Aug. 14, 2005, 435 F. Supp. 2d 1340 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (Panel orders to district where manufacturer's headquarters located).

In re Korean Air Lines Disaster of Sept. 1, 1983, 575 F. Supp. 342, 343 (J.P.M.L. 1983); see also In re Air Crash over the Southern Indian Ocean, on March 8, 2014, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Practice of Naturopathy Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1240, 1243 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
See In re Air Crash Disaster at Gander, Newfoundland, on Dec. 12, 1985, 633 F. Supp. 50 (J.P.M.L. 1986).

In re Air Crash Near Castellon, Spain on October 10, 2001, 296 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2003). See also In re Air Crash Near Athens, Greece, on Aug. 14, 2005, 435 F. Supp. 2d 1340 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (Panel also notes manufacturer's headquarters located in district).
In re Air Crash at Georgetown, Guyana, On July 30, 2011, 895 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2012).

See, e.g., In re Rail Collision Near Chase, Md. on Jan. 4, 1987, 661 F. Supp. 69 (J.P.M.L. 1987); In re Fire Disaster at Dupont Plaza Hotel, San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Dec. 31, 1986, 660 F. Supp. 982 (J.P.M.L. 1987); In re Continental Grain Co., Inc., 482 F. Supp. 330, 333 (J.P.M.L. 1979) (explosion); In re Liquid Carbonic Truck Drivers Chemical Poisoning Litigation, 423 F. Supp. 937 (J.P.M.L. 1976) (shipments from transferee district); In re Radiation Incident at Washington, D. C. on April 5, 1974, 400 F. Supp. 1404 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Bomb Disaster at Roseville, California, on April 28, 1973, 399 F. Supp. 1400, 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Silver Bridge Disaster, 311 F. Supp. 1345 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
In re Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Data Theft Litigation, 461 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
